On these forced switches, it can also set up Spikes or Stealth Rock, which further chips down switch-ins for the rest of the game due to the limited distribution of entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Whirlwind prevents opposing setup threats such as Double Dance Miraidon and Calm Mind Arceus-Ground from snowballing out of control, as well as using its own Spikes for chip damage. Protect can also be used in this moveslot, which allows for more Leftovers recovery and scouting of Choice item users and Tera types. The preference will come down to how much the team relies on Ting-Lu to phaze setup threats such as Calm Mind Arceus and Miraidon.
  • Leftovers is mandatory on Ting-Lu since it does not have any form of reliable recovery.
  • Ting-Lu will very rarely need to use its Tera types, as its natural typing provides a strong Electric immunity for Miraidon. Tera Steel provides a Dragon resistance versus Miraidon while also letting Ting-Lu handle Dazzling Gleam from Calm Mind + Tera Fairy Miraidon, and it also grants an immunity to Toxic from Eternatus and Toxapex. Tera Fairy provides a Dragon immunity against Miraidon, allowing Ting-Lu to better answer Tera Dragon sets with Calm Mind or Choice Specs, and Ting-Lu becomes resistant or immune to Koraidon's STAB moves. However, this comes at the expense of not resisting Fairy versus Tera Fairy Miraidon. Poison resists Close Combat and Zacian-C's Play Rough, and it allows Ting-Lu to absorb Toxic Spikes. Tera Water allows it to take Kyogre's STAB moves while also resisting Koraidon's Flare Blitz. It also lets Ting-Lu check the rare, but otherwise hard to check, Chi-Yu and Walking Wake. While all of these are good options for Ting-Lu, it benefits much more from its natural typing and should only Terastallize as a last resort.
  • Ting-Lu can also switch in safely against most defensive Pokemon in the tier, such as support Arceus formes, Groudon, Skeledirge, Giratina-O, and Toxapex, and then use this opportunity to set up a hazard or generate chip damage with Ruination.
  • It struggles against physical threats such as Koraidon, Zacian-C, and Arceus, so it is best paired with Pokemon such as defensive Arceus-Fairy, Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex that can switch into them reliably. Ting-Lu can also enable teammates such as Choice Scarf Koraidon, Miraidon, and Kyogre to clean more easily with the chip damage it generates from Ruination.
  • Due to Ting-Lu being unable to reliably check Choice Specs Miraidon long-term, it’s best to have some form of speed control alongside it, whether it be Choice Scarf Koraidon or Zacian-C.
  • Ting-Lu can function as a team's sole special wall, but it does appreciate naturally bulky Pokemon such as Kyogre and Groudon to handle some hits, which lets Ting-Lu remain a reliable Miraidon check. It can also pair well alongside the tier's Defoggers, Giratina-O and Corviknight as it is prone to Spikes chip damage and appreciates avoiding that to better check Miraidon. In a similar vein, Eternatus and Toxapex are good Toxic Spikes absorbers, the former of which can also soft check Kyogre and special Arceus formes.

sets.name: Feesh (Offensive Wallbreaker)
sets.description:
• Overheat hits extremely hard and can 2HKO even the bulkiest of Pokemon. Fire Blast and Flamethrower can be used to KO foes without Chi-Yu suffering a Special Attack drop, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy.
  • The only reason to run Timid over Modest is to outspeed Jolly Great Tusk, Jolly Annihilape, and fast Iron Treads with Special Defense investment.
  • Tera Fire allows Chi-Yu to turn 2HKOs to OHKOs, for example OHKOing opposing Chi-Yu with Overheat. Tera Fire also lets it 2HKO any prominent special wall, including Toxapex, Blissey, and Ting-Lu, OHKOing them with sun.
  • Choice Specs Chi-Yu is a wallbreaker, suited best for offensive teams. Koraidon is an excellent teammate because it sets sun and pivots Chi-Yu in with U-turn. Koraidon and Chi-Yu also threaten each other's checks, like Koraidon threatening Blissey and Garganacl and Chi-Yu threatening Skeledirge and Dondozo.
  • Helpful teammates are those that can get Chi-Yu in safely and force out its few checks. Corviknight and Koraidon are noteworthy examples, pivoting into special walls such as Ting-Lu. Lures such as Heavy Slam Koraidon and Great Tusk, which beat Dachsbun, and Psyshock Flutter Mane, which beats Toxapex and Blissey, are also appreciated teammates.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Fire Blast is Chi-Yu's strongest STAB move without any stat drops. Psychic is an alternative that 2HKOes common switch-ins such as Dachsbun and Toxapex. Overheat facilitates revenge killing, hitting even Pokemon that resist it such as Koraidon hard, and is a better midground play.
  • Memento serves as a way to facilitate sweepers like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon that Chi-Yu is usually paired with.
  • Tera Fire powers up Flamethrower and Overheat to nuclear levels, turning 2HKOs against Pokemon such as Koraidon into OHKOs. Tera Dark nullifies Chi-Yu's Stealth Rock weakness while making Dark Pulse 2HKO Dachsbun and Toxapex. Tera Grass should only be used with Tera Blast; it gives Chi-Yu nice resistances to Ground and Water and allows Chi-Yu to OHKO Great Tusk and 2HKO Ting-Lu after Spikes damage.
  • Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a revenge killer best suited for offensive teams.
  • Pokemon that can get Chi-Yu safely into the field, such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Corviknight, are excellent teammates for it. Koraidon also sets up sun, further boosting Chi-Yu's Fire-type attacks.
  • Ting-Lu and Glimmora can set entry hazards to guarantee some 2HKOs, such as against opposing Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot Chi-Yu can threaten to KO foes it couldn't otherwise, such as Ting-Lu and Blissey. Overheat hits extremely hard and threatens to OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Flamethrower is valuable for its perfect accuracy.
  • A Modest nature alongside Life Orb lets Chi-Yu OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used instead to give Chi-Yu more opportunities to switch in, but the loss of power is notable.
  • Chi-Yu fits best on offensive teams with Pokemon such as Cyclizar and Grimmsnarl that can facilitate its setup. Sticky Web support from Masquerain is also useful, as it lets Chi-Yu outrun Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon and KO them at +2.
  • Chi-Yu's best partner is Koraidon, since it sets up sun, can safely bring Chi-Yu into play with U-turn, and threatens Blissey. Other good partners are special attackers that benefit from special walls being neutered by Chi-Yu, such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo. Great Tusk is also greatly appreciated, as it can remove Stealth Rock and threatens Blissey and Ting-Lu for Chi-Yu. Chi-Yu can deal with Corviknight and Dondozo in return.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With Dragon Dance and Acrobatics, Roaring Moon is a strong sweeper on offensive teams, with coverage to beat almost all Pokemon.
  • Tera Flying allows Roaring Moon to set up on Great Tusk and Body Press Corviknight and boosts Acrobatics's power to achieve feats such as OHKOing Toxapex and Ting-Lu after two Dragon Dances and entry hazard or slight chip damage.
  • Crunch is more reliable, having a chance to drop Defense with no potential drawback, while Jaw Lock has the potential to give Roaring Moon a free chance to set up when paired with Roost, assuming a favorable target is trapped. If an unfavorable target is trapped, however, it has a major downside, making it less consistent.
  • Roost gives Roaring Moon more opportunities to use Dragon Dance, turning weaker Pokemon like Brave Bird Corviknight and Whirpool Alomomola into setup fodder.
  • Earthquake hits Kingambit, Garganacl, and Iron Treads, which can otherwise survive hits and wear down Roaring Moon.
  • Taunt stops defensive Pokemon like Haze Toxapex, Will-O-Wisp Skeledirge, and Whirlwind Ting-Lu from dealing with Roaring Moon, making it devastating against bulkier teams if positioned right.
  • Hyper offense leads such as Glimmora, Froslass, and Grimmsnarl all give Roaring Moon good support to break through a team more easily.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Tera Fire Koraidon, and Tera Fairy Miraidon can all be used to bait Chien-Pao and take it out, helping Roaring Moon greatly, as it is one of the most reliable revenge killers that can be used against it.
  • On bulkier teams, Roaring Moon requires teammates that can switch into Ice-type moves from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, making Toxapex and specially defensive Corviknight great partners. The latter can also pivot with U-turn, giving Roaring Moon more chances to set up on defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Full Moon (Choice Band)
sets.description:
• Earthquake lets Roaring Moon break past Pokemon that would otherwise check it, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and especially Kingambit.
  • Iron Head lets Roaring Moon hit Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Tera Fairy Garganacl and Skeledirge super effectively.
  • U-turn lets Roaring Moon generate offensive momentum for its team and is especially useful against targets Roaring Moon scares out, like Skeledirge without Tera Fairy and Gholdengo.
  • The given EVs and a Jolly nature ensure Roaring Moon's Speed is boosted in sunlight, letting it get the jump on crucial threats like unboosted non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon and threaten them with its STAB Dragon Claw. The remaining 36 Special Defense EVs improve Roaring Moon's chances to survive Iron Bundle's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock while giving it a chance to survive Overheat in sun from Modest Choice Specs Chi-Yu.
  • Tera Dark strengthens Roaring Moon's Crunch to the point where it always 2HKOs physically defensive Corviknight and always 3HKOs Dondozo while easing predictions with Earthquake against Garganacl.
  • Tera Steel lets Roaring Moon resist otherwise super effective Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, Koraidon, and Miraidon. Tera Steel also powers up Roaring Moon's Iron Head.
  • Tera Fairy allows Roaring Moon to resist Fighting-type attacks while becoming immune to Dragon-type attacks, letting it defeat Koraidon and Iron Valiant, both of which outspeed and threaten to OHKO Roaring Moon otherwise.
  • Roaring Moon loves the support of Koraidon, as it activates Roaring Moon's Protosynthesis via Orichalcum Pulse and reliably threatens Pokemon such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Ice-types like Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. In return, Roaring Moon threatens non-Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Koraidon and Roaring Moon both struggle with defensive Great Tusk, so they can team up with Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao, which threaten all Great Tusk sets. Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao also threaten Koraidon and Miraidon, with Iron Bundle naturally outspeeding non-Choice Scarf variants and Chien-Pao threatening them with priority Ice Shard.
  • Defensive Great Tusk and Ting-Lu also work well with Roaring Moon, as they can set up entry hazards for Roaring Moon's team and check Koraidon and Miraidon, respectively. Great Tusk in particular can use Rapid Spin, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in, while Ting-Lu can phaze threatening boosters like Espathra with Whirlwind and set up Spikes.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight can check Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, both of which outspeed and threaten Roaring Moon, and can Defog hazards away, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in.
  • Roaring Moon can easily pivot into Chi-Yu, which takes advantage of the sun set by Koraidon and threatens walls like Great Tusk, Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Gholdengo also makes for a decent partner, as not only does it have perfect defensive synergy with Roaring Moon, but it can also reliably block all common forms of hazard removal. This allows Roaring Moon’s team to keep up hazards, in particular Spikes, for it to eventually break down walls.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
• Life Orb Iron Valiant is a strong wallbreaker that can threaten common walls such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Skeledirge, Blissey, and Toxapex.
  • Thunderbolt is a good coverage move to hit Corviknight and Toxapex hard and is especially powerful under Electric Terrain. Psyshock is Iron Valiant's strongest option for breaking through Clodsire.
  • Knock Off lets Iron Valiant wear down potential checks by removing Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots. Shadow Ball hits most targets neutrally and Skeledirge and Scream Tail, which would otherwise wall it, super effectively. However, this option is outclassed by Knock Off and Psyshock.
  • Tera Fairy makes Iron Valiant's Moonblast immensely strong while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams thanks to its ability to outspeed and KO common offensive foes while under Electric Terrain, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk, while pressuring walls including Ting-Lu, Corviknight, Clodsire, and Toxapex. However, Life Orb recoil and the ever-present entry hazards make it difficult for Iron Valiant to maintain pressure in longer games, and common, faster wallbreakers, such as Scarf Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Protosynthesis-boosted Flutter Mane, force Iron Valiant out.
  • Miraidon is a fantastic partner for Iron Valiant thanks to it providing Electric Terrain support and pivoting Iron Valiant in with U-turn. In return, Iron Valiant can take on Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Blissey, and Chien-Pao for Miraidon while switching into Dragon moves from opposing Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Wallbreakers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane appreciate Iron Valiant breaking through Corviknight and Toxapex while they take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk and Skeledirge are great teammates for dealing with Koraidon, which can take on any of Iron Valiant's attacks with Tera Fire and set up sun to make it harder for Iron Valiant to revenge kill Flutter Mane.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight is a fantastic partner for soft checking Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane while removing entry hazards with Defog. Great Tusk also clears hazards, making it easier for Iron Valiant to consistently come in during a match.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance Iron Valiant functions as a decent setup sweeper for offensive teams, thanks to its good coverage and high Speed with Quark Drive and Booster Energy.
  • Knock Off annihilates Gholdengo and is Iron Valiant's best option against Skeledirge.
  • Alternatively, Shadow Sneak OHKOes Flutter Mane after a Swords Dance boost, which otherwise outspeed Iron Valiant in the sun.
  • Iron Valiant excels against teams that rely on defensive Great Tusk as their main check to physical attackers, so teammates that appreciate Great Tusk being gone, such as Koraidon, are recommended.
  • Skeledirge completely walls Iron Valiant, with Iron Valiant only being able to remove it's Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off. This is exacerbated thanks to the nature of Booster Energy only activating once.
  • As a result, special attackers such as Miraidon, Iron Moth, and Chi-Yu are recommended, with Miraidon's Electric Terrain allowing Iron Valiant to keep Booster Energy longer, while the latter two's burn immunity grants them an easy time switching in.
  • Lures to Skeledirge such as Outrage or Stomping Tantrum Koraidon are also useful.
  • Even after Booster Energy is activated, Speed-boosted Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane as well as Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon can revenge kill Iron Valiant without much issue. Due to this, Grimmsnarl is a helpful teammate, as its Reflect and Light Screen support makes revenge killing Iron Valiant more difficult.
  • Spikes support from Froslass or Glimmora is greatly appreciated, as a layer of Spikes will guarantee the OHKO on Great Tusk from +2 Tera Fairy Spirit Break, not to mention Iron Valiant's Knock Off naturally pairs well with entry hazards.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
• Booster Energy Iron Valiant is a good anti-offense Pokemon, as it outspeeds and revenge kills many hyper offense staples such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Miraidon.
  • Thunderbolt hits Toxapex and Corviknight hard, while Focus Blast is Iron Valiant's strongest STAB option against Tera Steel Pokemon like Ting-Lu which would otherwise check Iron Valiant. Focus Blast also 2HKOes Blissey after a Calm Mind boost, something that Psyshock fails to do.
  • Psyshock hits Unaware Clodsire and the rare Iron Moth for super effective damage. Shadow Ball, on the other hand, hits Skeledirge, Iron Valiant's biggest roadblock, but it doesn't offer much outside of that.
  • Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast while retaining Iron Valiant's useful defensive niche against Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. However, Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes Toxapex and Corviknight without a boost. It also makes Iron Valiant immune to Thunder Wave and removes its weakness to Steel-type attacks.
  • Booster Energy Iron Valiant is best suited for offensive teams and, as such, should be used offensively, using its perfect coverage to break enemy walls and revenge kill threats to its team.
  • Miraidon is Iron Valiant's best teammate, as it sets Electric Terrain, letting Iron Valiant conceal its item; it also powers up Thunderbolt and can get Iron Valiant safely into the field with U-turn. Iron Valiant, in return, deals with Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Blissey for Miraidon. Other hyper offense Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and Dragonite appreciate Iron Valiant for its good matchup against other offensive teams.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Iron Valiant is a potent offensive threat that is difficult to switch into thanks to its spammable STAB attacks and high Speed under Electric Terrain.
  • Thunderbolt breaks through Corviknight and Toxapex and is further boosted by Electric Terrain. Shadow Ball pressures Skeledirge and Scream Tail, but Psyshock is an option to beat Clodsire, which would wall this set otherwise.
  • Fairy is Iron Valiant's best Tera type, as it makes its Moonblast incredibly difficult to switch into, threatening to OHKO Flutter Mane, while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take on common Dark- and Dragon-types such as Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, Miraidon, and Koraidon. Iron Valiant also helps break past walls such as Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex, which are roadblocks for its teammates such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Miraidon is the best partner for Iron Valiant thanks to powering up Thunderbolt, boosting its Speed because of Quark Drive, and pivoting into Iron Valiant with U-turn. Similarly, wallbreakers such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao appreciate Iron Valiant breaking Corviknight and Toxapex, and they can take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant in return. Finally, Skeledirge uses Corviknight as setup fodder, and Great Tusk threatens Tera Fire Koraidon for Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Koraidon is one of the best revenge killers in Ubers thanks to its high Attack and Speed.
  • Low Kick is usually preferred over Collision Course due to it hitting most Pokemon harder in the heavy Ubers tier.
  • Dragon Claw is a reliable Dragon-type STAB move, while Outrage usually 2HKOes Skeledirge. This can force it to use Tera Fairy, which Zacian-C can take advantage of.
  • U-turn allows Koraidon to take advantage of predictable switches to Skeledirge or Groudon and bring in dangerous wallbreakers, such as Flutter Mane, Chi-Yu, Walking Wake, or Kyogre. Be careful not to use U-turn too much when facing Rocky Helmet users like Toxapex.
  • Flare Blitz hits targets like Arceus-Fairy hard, especially when boosted by Tera Fire. Tera Fire also prevents burns from Skeledirge or Giratina-O and gives Koraidon a useful Fairy resistance.
  • Tera Steel is a good option for the myriad of resistances it brings, most notably Normal for E-Killer Arceus, Dragon for opposing Koraidon or Miraidon, and Fairy against Arceus-Fairy or Zacian-C.
  • As a revenge killer, Koraidon provides numerous advantages compared to others, such as having high Defense and Fighting-type STAB moves to take on E-Killer Arceus, and attacking physically lets it heavily damage Calm Mind Arceus formes.
  • It's nigh on impossible for this Koraidon to break past Skeledirge, Toxapex, or Dondozo reliably, so pairing Koraidon with strong wallbreakers that can take advantage of U-turn is a must.
  • Arceus-Fairy takes on Koraidon well and doesn't mind U-turn, so checks to Arceus-Fairy such as Skeledirge, Zacian-C, and Clodsire are good partners.
  • Flare Blitz recoil, Rocky Helmet damage, and entry hazards can quickly pile up damage on this Koraidon, so having a solid defensive core is recommended so you don't have to rely on Koraidon's revenge killing as much.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Choice Band Koraidon has no reliable switch-ins, thus making it one of the most powerful wallbreakers in the tier.
  • Low Kick makes for a strong STAB move with few drawbacks, as it often sports high Base Power in the Ubers tier. Close Combat is the preferred Fighting-type STAB move when running Tera Fighting, as it has a chance to 2HKO both Toxapex, which takes little from Low Kick, and most Arceus-Fairy sets outright.
  • Dragon Claw usually 2HKOes Skeledirge and is a reliable Dragon-type STAB move, so it tends to be preferred over Outrage. Outrage does sport overwhelming power and can 2HKO Toxapex and Alomomola, which Dragon Claw cannot do without entry hazard support. This is particularly notable for Tera Steel sets, which may otherwise lack enough breaking power.
  • Flare Blitz is a very strong move under the sun and becomes incredibly powerful when boosted by Tera Fire, to the point that it even 2HKOes Fire-resistant Pokemon like Skeledirge and Toxapex. Tera Fire has the additional benefit of granting a Fairy resistance and a burn immunity.
  • While not providing any boost in offensive power, Tera Steel offers several useful resistances to Fairy, Ice, and Dragon, which can help Koraidon take on Pokemon like Zacian-C, Miraidon, Arceus-Fairy, and Chien-Pao.
  • Choice Band Koraidon is an insanely powerful wallbreaker that can break past all of its normal checks and switch-ins. However, it tends to be worn down easily due to being vulnerable to all entry hazards and often taking Rocky Helmet damage and Flare Blitz recoil. Thus, it pairs best with teammates like Zacian-C, which can clean up after Koraidon has broken down the main defensive core. Koraidon's breaking power allows Zacian-C the flexibility to run coverage options outside of Tera Blast such as Crunch and Wild Charge, and Zacian-C provides the team with a revenge killer as well, making the two a particularly good pair.
  • Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy sets also work well with Choice Band Koraidon, as Arceus-Fairy can sweep much easier once Skeledirge and Toxapex are taken out of the picture.
  • Koraidon provides excellent utility for teams that are looking for a way to force out Calm Mind Arceus formes, Calm Mind Kyogre, and Calm Mind Cresselia, as its higher Speed and overwhelming physical power can easily break past the aforementioned foes.
  • Koraidon tends to be revenge killed by Zacian-C, opposing Choice Scarf Koraidon, and Choice Scarf Miraidon. As such, sporting a solid defensive core with Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex is critical for Koraidon's success.

sets.name: Life Orb Attacker
sets.description:
• Koraidon is one of, if not the strongest, wallbreakers in the tier. Life Orb gives it a crucial power boost that allows it to knock defensive staples out in a single hit after setting up a Swords Dance. Groudon, Toxapex, any Arceus forme, Landorus-T, Kyogre, and others can be knocked out in a single hit, even if they adapt fully defensive EV spreads.
  • Low Kick is a powerful STAB move that takes advantage of the heavy weight of most Pokemon in the metagame. This is better than Close Combat, as it doesn't drop Koraidon's defenses while still having 120 Base Power against crucial targets.
  • Stomping Tantrum allows Koraidon to 2HKO Toxapex and Skeledirge without power boosts. However, if the prior move failed, Stomping Tantrum will do double damage and OHKO Skeledirge. This is triggered when Skeledirge switches into Low Kick, for instance.
  • Swords Dance is one of the most important moves in Koraidon's arsenal, allowing it to get OHKOs on anything that doesn't have the Unaware ability, as long as Koraidon has the right moves for the situation.
  • Flame Charge is the key to Koraidon's sweeping abilities because of the Speed boost it provides in addition to the Fire-type coverage with no recoil. Usually, Flame Charge needs the boost from Tera Fire to fix its low Base Power and allow Koraidon to pick up KOs on healthier targets.
  • Flare Blitz is a more powerful alternative to Flame Charge, which makes Koraidon significantly less reliant on Terastallization to score KOs on the opponent's defensive Pokemon like Arceus-Fairy after Swords Dance. This can open up opportunities for its fellow sweeping teammates.
  • Dragon Claw fixes Koraidon's issues with Rayquaza and Giratina; however, it does make Koraidon much less threatening against Skeledirge and Toxapex, as it can no longer 2HKO either.
  • Life Orb is the key to Koraidon's functioning. Life Orb is absolutely necessary, as the power boost and recoil differentiate how this Koraidon is used compared to its other sets.
  • Tera Fire is necessary, as it gives Koraidon an immunity to Will-O-Wisp, resistances to Fairy and Steel, and a huge power boost to Koraidon's Fire-type attacks. This is especially efficient with Flame Charge and is often key to enabling Koraidon to sweep.
  • Life Orb Koraidon fits well on any remotely offensively-minded team because it has the ability to lure in defensive Pokemon and beat them due to its unexpected Life Orb-boosted power. This can be used to open up teammates like Swords Dance, Dragon Dance, or offensive Calm Mind Arceus formes, Zacian-C, and Double Dance Miraidon.

sets.name: Swords Dance + 3 Attacks
sets.description:
• Low Kick is Koraidon’s best attack, having 120 Base Power against many relevant threats like Arceus, Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Kyogre. However, Collision Course can be used for universal damage, as well as threatening Ting-Lu and Extreme Killer Arceus harder.
  • Tera Fire gives Koraidon resistances to Fairy and Steel, letting it handle Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy. It also boosts Flame Charge‘s power to the point it is able to OHKO Zacian-C without a boost. However, it makes Koraidon weak to common attacks like Arceus-Ground’s Earthquake, Arceus-Fairy’s Earth Power, and Kyogre’s Surf or Origin Pulse. Stealth Rock also cuts into Koraidon a lot more as Tera Fire makes Koraidon weak to it.
  • Swords Dance Koraidon is a sweeper best used mid- or late-game on offensive teams, when its checks and counters have been worn down enough for Koraidon to break through them.
  • The abundance of Pokemon that can effectively Terastallize into the Fairy typing, like Miraidon and Eternatus, hurts Koraidon, as it is not strong enough to break these Pokemon with just Flame Charge. Baiting out Terastallization earlier in the game massively helps out Koraidon, as that ensures it can no longer be revenge killed by a defensive Tera Fairy when going for a sweep.
  • Kyogre setting up rain hurts Koraidon, as rain removes Koraidon’s Orichalcum Pulse boost and weakens Flame Charge, making it much easier to play around. However, Kyogre has no reliable recovery, so it can be chipped to the point where it can no longer compete with Koraidon’s sun.
  • Physical walls like Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Dondozo are by far Koraidon’s best counters, so Koraidon appreciates teammates that can threaten them, like Miraidon, Kyogre, and Flutter Mane. Flutter Mane in particular loves Koraidon’s sun activating Protosynthesis for it.
  • Physical attackers like Zacian-C, Arceus-Ground, and Groudon can all threaten damage on defensive Landorus-T, Groudon, and Arceus-Fairy, which can comfortably take on Koraidon at high HP but can easily get overwhelmed by both these physically offensive Pokemon and Koraidon.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Miraidon is perhaps the best wallbreaker in Ubers, with the extra power allowing Draco Meteor to 2HKO Clodsire and Arceus-Ground.
  • U-turn is useful to gain momentum on predictable switches as well as not revealing Miraidon's item. Volt Switch does the same thing with much more power but requires that the opposing team's Ground-types be eliminated first.
  • Overheat annihilates Iron Treads, and since immunities to both of Miraidon's STAB attacks are common, it can ease prediction against players attempting to cycle between Ground- and Fairy-types.
  • Tera Dragon allows Miraidon to 2HKO Ting-Lu, one of the only Pokemon capable of taking two consecutive Choice Specs Draco Meteors.
  • Tera Electric lets Miraidon break nearly any Pokemon without an Electric immunity in the game, even 2HKOing Blissey outright. Tera Electric is also useful to overpower Calm Mind Arceus formes without the Special Attack drop from Draco Meteor.
  • Since Choice Specs Miraidon has no reliable check in the metagame, it works excellently as a wallbreaker for the vast majority of teams.
  • Its ability to break or greatly weaken Ting-Lu is a boon for teammates like Calm Mind Arceus-Ghost, Arceus-Poison, Arceus-Ground, and Arceus-Dark and is helpful to prevent Ting-Lu from laying Spikes at all.
  • Miraidon can lure in and KO Clodsire, so Pokemon that appreciate Clodsire taken out make good partners such as Eternatus, Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy, and Kyogre.
  • Physically offensive teammates like Zacian-C can make for good partners, as Miraidon can come in on many of their checks such as Skeledirge and Toxapex with little worry.
  • Since Miraidon can quickly overwhelm Ting-Lu and Clodsire, it's important to anticipate Tera Steel or Tera Fairy from them and react accordingly.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Life Orb Miraidon is one of the fiercest wallbreakers in the Ubers tier, having a 50% chance to OHKO Ting-Lu outright with a Calm Mind and Tera Dragon-boosted Draco Meteor.
  • Parabolic Charge OHKOes Zacian-C at +1 and provides Miraidon with a source of healing to counteract Life Orb, Substitute, and entry hazard damage. This also usually lets Miraidon win against Blissey without Tera Ground. Electro Drift's higher damage output allows Miraidon to OHKO bulky Arceus-Fairy sets and OHKO Zacian-C from behind a Substitute.
  • The fourth slot is flexible. Substitute eases prediction and can take advantage of passive walls and foes that attempt to pivot around Miraidon. Overheat nails Iron Treads and can also hit Ting-Lu or Clodsire, which often use Tera Steel on Miraidon's Draco Meteor, and it can also be used as a neutral hit to prevent switching between Ground- and Fairy-types to stall out Electric Terrain turns. Taunt can help prevent setup from Pokemon that could take advantage of Miraidon after a Draco Meteor stat drop such as Calm Mind Arceus formes and Ting-Lu or Clodsire using Spikes.
  • If the opponent has not already Terastallized, care should be taken when facing Ting-Lu and Clodsire, as their Tera Steel or Tera Fairy can turn the tide against Miraidon quickly. While this leaves both foes open to being chipped down, Miraidon can in turn be hit by Whirlwind, Toxic, or damaged heavily outright by Earthquake and Ruination. If Miraidon wins the exchange, it's often left at low HP and open to being revenge killed.
  • This set works excellently on Sticky Web teams in particular, as it greatly appreciates being able to outspeed Zacian-C and Choice Scarf Pokemon like Eternatus. At the same time, it also works excellently for bulky offense and balance teams that are seeking a solid way to break opposing balance and stall teams.
  • Spikes support can be crucial for this set, as the chip damage can guarantee the OHKO on opposing Ting-Lu; Ting-Lu, Groudon, or Clodsire can set up Spikes for Miraidon.
  • Arceus formes such as Arceus-Ghost, Arceus-Ground, and Arceus-Dark make for good offensive partners, as all of them like Ting-Lu being taken out of the picture.
  • Zacian-C is a huge annoyance thanks to its higher Speed and Dragon-type immunity; as such, solid checks to it such as Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex are much appreciated. Lures for Zacian-C such as Thunder Wave Arceus-Fairy or Arceus-Grass can cripple Zacian-C and leave it as an easy target for Miraidon later in the game.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf makes Miraidon an effective revenge killer, late-game sweeper, and pivot, taking advantage of its great Speed, naturally amazing offenses, and access to U-turn. Its most important application is being able to outspeed Koraidon, Flutter Mane, opposing Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Speed-boosted Arceus.
  • Electro Drift allows Miraidon to hit a lot of Pokemon for neutral damage, most notably Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy, which are immune to Draco Meteor.
  • Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move that allows Miraidon to deal with slower Dragon-types as well as hit a lot of Pokemon for neutral damage, most notably Ground-types.
  • Overheat can OHKO Zacian-C, hit foes trying to pivot between Ground- and Fairy-types, and damage neutral targets in sun, which makes it is as strong as Draco Meteor.
  • U-turn helps Miraidon pivot out of the Ground-type Pokemon that are used to check it.
  • Dragon Pulse can be used instead of Overheat to increase consistency and prevent the opponent from exploiting the drawbacks of Draco Meteor.
  • Volt Switch can be used instead of Electro Drift to keep up the momentum after attacking.
  • Tera Electric allows Miraidon to power up its Electro Drift and make itself less exploitable, OHKOing Zacian-C and dealing massive damage to most Arceus formes. This is an especially devastating end-game cleanup tool after the opposing Ground-types have been removed.
  • Tera Steel gives Miraidon a Normal- and Dragon-type, resistance which allows it to take a hit from Pokemon like Extreme Killer Arceus and opposing Miraidon. Tera Steel also gives it resistances to both of Zacian-C's STAB moves.
  • Tera Dragon powers up its Dragon-type attacks, which allows Miraidon to break through Ting-Lu and Clodsire and pick up KOs from higher ranges of health on other neutral targets like Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground.
  • This set fits best on balance teams where it can help ease off the pressure from its defensively oriented teammates like Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu by outrunning and forcing your opponent's offensive Pokemon to switch out.
  • Miraidon can also help teammates like Zacian-C, Koraidon, Kyogre, and Chien-Pao with U-turn, which would allow them to get into favorable positions such as against Ting-Lu and potentially force your opponent into having to switch again.
  • Some teammates that can lure in and weaken Ting-Lu are Eternatus and Toxapex, which can use Toxic and Toxic Spikes, your own Ting-Lu with Ruination, and Giratina-O, which can status and phaze the opposing team with Dragon Tail. This greatly helps Miraidon because Ting-Lu is Miraidon's most common check.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Miraidon is a powerful pivot, being able to comfortably 2HKO most Pokemon in the tier with Electro Drift. Draco Meteor allows it to wear down any reliable Electro Drift switch-in, and U-turn enables Miraidon to bring in its teammates with ease.
  • Taunt can stop opposing Arceus formes and Clodsire from clicking Recover and Ting-Lu and Groudon from setting up hazards. It can also stop setup from the likes of Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy, Calm Mind or Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground, and Dragon Dance Arceus.
  • Miraidon is required to run 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature or it runs the risk of underspeeding Eternatus, Arceus, and Arceus-Ground.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Miraidon from taking unnecessary chip damage from hazards, which are set most of the time due to the lack of reliable hazard removal in the tier. This gives pivot Miraidon more longevity compared to boosting items and allows it to bring in its teammates for longer.
  • Tera Dragon and Tera Electric give Miraidon's STAB moves a power boost, allowing it to 2HKO Ting-Lu with Draco Meteor and to 2HKO specially defensive Arceus-Fairy with Electro Drift, respectively.
  • Miraidon is best used alongside setup threats such as the aforementioned Arceus formes, Swords Dance Koraidon, and Swords Dance Zacian-C to deny opposing walls entry hazards and recoveryand chip them with its powerful Electric- and Dragon-type STAB moves.
  • It can struggle to deal with Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and bulky Arceus formes due to lacking power compared to Choice Specs sets, so it appreciates teammates such as Koraidon, Zacian-C and Flutter Mane that can reliably come in on them after it uses U-turn.
  • Pivot Miraidon can form a strong momentum core with other pivots such as Landorus-T and Koraidon to provide chip damage for other teammates to clean.
  • Teams with it do require some form of alternative speed control such as Zacian-C, Choice Scarf Koraidon, and Flutter Mane, as Miraidon is unable to outpace other threats itself.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description: Agility makes Miraidon a lethal late-game sweeper, taking advantage of its natural good Speed to outspeed every Pokemon on the metagame at +2 without major Speed investment, allowing for more bulk investment to live hits it normally wouldn't be able to. Roseli Berry helps Miraidon take a Play Rough from Zacian-C or Judgement from Arceus-Fairy, allowing it to set up against them more easily. Electric Seed provides a +1 Defense boost, allowing it to have easier setup opportunities against physical attackers. Parabolic Charge allows Miraidon to recover health while also doing consistent damage. On the other hand, Electro Drift is a stronger move that OHKOes Zacian after one layer of Spikes. Dragon Pulse can be used with Tera Dragon, while Dazzling Gleam is used exclusively on Tera Fairy Tera Fairy is an amazing defensive typing that turns its weaknesses into neutralities and grants it a Dragon-type immunity, letting it 2HKO Ting-Lu after one layer of Spikes and OHKO opposing Miraidon and Koraidon with STAB Dazzling Gleam. However, this set is completely walled by Clodsire. Tera Dragon powers up Dragon Pulse, which allows Miraidon to 2HKO Ting-Lu and Clodsire with a 2 HKO at +1 after Spikes damage and pick up KOs from higher ranges of health on other neutral targets like Arceus-Ground. This set should be considered on either balance offense teams as a cleaner or hyper offense sweeper that can break open the opposing team. Partners in hyper Offense teams such as dual screens Grimmsnarl allow it to easily set up and sweep. On the other hand, leads such as Meowscarada and Froslass can aid Miraidon's sweep by setting up Spikes to weaken opposing Pokemon into range of Miraidon's attacks. Miraidon benefits from partners that can allow it to break its checks much more easily such as Arceus-Fairy, Arceus-Ground, Kyogre. and Koraidon. It also benefits from other teammates such as Eternatus that weaken their shared checks such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire for it.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Walking Wake is one of the most dangerous sun wallbreakers in Ubers, capable of 2HKOing even the bulkiest of Water resists and special walls alike.
  • Hydro Steam is Walking Wake's most spammable move; in sun, it 2HKOes Koraidon, OHKOes Flutter Mane, and 2HKOes Toxapex, making it very hard for teams to have a consistent switch-in to it.
  • Dragon Pulse, albeit weaker than Draco Meteor, doesn't come with any drawbacks, making it a much better move to spam if lowering Walking Wake's Special Attack is not desired.
  • Tera Water turns Walking Wake into an unwallable Pokemon, 2HKOing defensive walls like Blissey and OHKOing offensive pivots like Assault Vest Flutter Mane in sun. Tera Fairy can be used instead, as it gives Walking Wake useful resistances to Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao and Kingambit while also making it immune to Dragon-type attacks from Koraidon and Miraidon. Lastly, Tera Steel gives Walking Wake a resistance to Iron Bundle's Ice-type attacks, mainly Freeze Dry.
  • A Modest nature lets Walking Wake wallbreak with extreme ease, allowing for Draco Meteor to 2HKO Clodsire in sun. Alternatively, a Timid nature gets the jump on Timid Chi-Yu and opposing Modest Walking Wake, although the difference in power is very noticeable.
  • Walking Wake is best suited for offensive sun teams and should be used as such, making use of its unique typing to switch into Pokemon like Chi-Yu and counterattack with a nuclear Hydro Steam.
  • Walking Wake is somewhat slow for Ubers standards, so fast partners like Choice Scarf Koraidon and Flutter Mane are a must to compensate for its Speed stat. Koraidon's sun also greatly powers up Walking Wake's attacks.
  • Secondary wallbreakers such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu are also recommended, as Walking Wake's Speed hinders its performance as a standalone wallbreaker. Defensive teammates like Clodsire and Great Tusk are also helpful, as they check Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon, respectively.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Iron Leaves is a consistent wallbreaker in Electric Terrain thanks to its immense power and unique type combination. It can force out most walls and has a plethora of switch-in opportunities against the common Ground-types in the tier, such as Great Tusk and Ting-Lu.
  • Wild Charge is an important coverage option that allows it to hit Corviknight, which resists Iron Leaves's STAB moves. It also OHKOes Pelipper.
  • Close Combat hits the Steel-types that resist Iron Leaves's STAB moves, like Kingambit and Tera Steel users. Close Combat is also crucial for OHKOing Chi-Yu and Chien-Pao on the switch in.
  • Swords Dance is an alternative option that can be used over one of the coverage moves to punish foes trying to stall out Electric Terrain turns by predicting Protect or a switch.
  • Leftovers mitigates passive damage from hazards, Rocky Helmet, poison from Baneful Banker, and recoil from Wild Charge, providing Iron Leaves with some staying power. Iron Leaves with Leftovers and four attacks is best used as an early- to mid-game attacker that aims to create opportunities for teammates to sweep.
  • Life Orb gives an immense power boost but reduces Iron Leaves's longevity. It will be worn down severely by the time it manages to beat its check, which allows it less opportunities to attack afterwards. Notably, Life Orb allows Psyblade to OHKO Miraidon and 2HKO Skeledirge in Electric Terrain. Life Orb is best in combination with Swords Dance to minimize recoil. Using Iron Leaves this way is most potent mid- to late-game.
  • A Jolly nature is necessary to be able to outspeed Timid Chi-Yu and max Speed Palafin.
  • Tera Psychic is the main option to increase Psyblade damage, remove Ice and Fire weaknesses, and actually be able to take a U-turn in a pinch. Tera Psychic allows Iron Leaves to OHKO Koraidon without Electric Terrain, OHKO defensive Great Tusk and Miraidon in Electric Terrain, and guarantee a 2HKO on Skeledirge and Terastallized Alomomola. It's meant to be utilized with four attacks.
  • Tera Steel can be used to face off better against Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Kingambit. It also has the benefit of a Poison immunity, which can allow Iron Leaves to not get worn down by Baneful Bunker from Toxapex, and a U-turn resistance that can be used to catch the opponent off guard. This is a riskier Tera to commit to, as it makes Iron Leaves weak to both of Great Tusk's STAB moves instead of resisting them. Tera Steel is meant to be utilized with four attacks.
  • Tera Fighting gives Iron Leaves a Close Combat that OHKOes physically defensive Corviknight after a Swords Dance without Electric Terrain. Tera Fighting's defensive contributions are useful against the aforementioned Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and especially Kingambit. This Tera type is meant to be utilized with Swords Dance and Close Combat.
  • Tera Electric can be used to power up Wild Charge, which is useful against Corviknight and Tera Flying users like Kingambit, and it also gives Iron Leaves neutrality to all of its weaknesses. This Tera type is meant to be used with Swords Dance and Wild Charge to deal with Pokemon that resist Iron Leaves's STAB moves but are neutral to Electric. Tera Electric is the most risky, as you're investing your Terastallization for a Pokemon that's likely to KO itself quickly.
  • The biggest downside to Iron Leaves is how dependent it is on Electric Terrain to function properly. It can still be used to force out Great Tusk and Ting-Lu without Electric Terrain, but it's underwhelming compared to when Electric Terrain is active.
  • Miraidon is invaluable as a partner to Iron Leaves because it provides Electric Terrain and lures in Ground-types to U-turn on, which gives Iron Leaves a free switch. Specifically, Choice Scarf Miraidon is the best for the job, as it can provide Speed control and function as a late-game cleaner to take advantage of the holes Iron Leaves leaves behind.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight is a great partner, as it can also provide U-turn support to get Iron Leaves in, as well as make up for the Iron Bundle weakness Miraidon and Iron Leaves share. Corviknight can provide hazard control with Defog, but an additional Rapid Spinner like Great Tusk or Iron Treads is also advisable.
  • Iron Leaves fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, which also makes defensive pivots that are used in the archetype, like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, good partners.
